The zero matrix

We call \(B=\begin{bmatrix}0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\) the \(2 \times 2\) zero matrix written \(\underline{0}\) so that \(A \cdot \underline{0} = \underline{0} \cdot A = \underline{0}\) for any matrix \(A.\)

Now in the multiplication of numbers, the equation \(ab = 0\) implies that either \(a\) is zero or \(b\) is zero or both are zero. The following task shows that this is not necessarily true for matrices.
